poem:
Trade Winds  

In the shadow  
of agreements past,  
figures in gray suits  
whisper of bridges—  
lost, or just unseen?  
The horizon,  
a line of ink,  
pleads for trade's embrace;  
the old continent,  
a tethered partner  
beckoning,  
as tides of coins  
glisten between us,  
a currency of hopes  
unspent.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Bank of England governor urges EU trade rebuild as key summit looms The governor of the Bank of England has said that the UK now needs to do “everything we can” to rebuild its long-term trade relationship with the EU, after a breakthrough agreement with the US to reduce some of Donald Trump’s tariffs. Andrew Bailey said that while he would not pass judgment on the UK’s exit from the EU in early 2020, reversing". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
